content: The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. The Department of State claimed their sexual orientation made them security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining the Department. During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality, deemed security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining due to screening for being gay or lesbian. Congress shares responsibility for the Department's actions. The Department of State implemented a screening process to prevent hiring individuals who were perceived as gay or lesbian, partly in response to congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and pressure from Congress regarding the presence of homosexuals within the Department. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State had to report the number of homosexuals fired each year due to congressional pressure. The "Lavender Scare" had significant effects during this time. In the early 1990s, the Department of State's security office was investigating and removing gay personnel as "security risks". In the early 1990s, the Department of State's security office investigated and removed gay personnel as "security risks". By 1994, Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation, and in 1998, President Clinton signed an Executive Order barring such discrimination. In 1998, President Clinton signed Executive Order 13087 prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation in the Department of State. In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for past discriminatory practices and reaffirmed the commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community. SEC. 3. DIRECTOR GENERAL REVIEW. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made publicly available within 270 days of the enactment of this Act, including historical statements from Department of State officials. The Director General will compile information on wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation and create a report within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include historical statements from Department of State and Congress officials. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of Director General's reviews under section 3 and submit reports to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations. Designate a senior-level point of contact within the Office of the Director General of the Foreign Service to receive testimony from affected employees or their families regarding the "Lavender Scare" firings. Contact all fired employees or their families to offer to change their employment records to reflect the inappropriate terminations. Designate a senior-level point of contact within the Office of the Director General of the Foreign Service to receive testimony from affected employees or their families regarding discriminatory policies based on sexual orientation. Testimony will serve as an official record of the impact on United States lives. The Board will review claims of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation, allowing affected employees or their families to provide testimony for an official record. Former employees not mentioned in the report can also bring forth grievances if they believe they were terminated due to their sexual orientation. The Board will review claims of discrimination and termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days of receiving the claim. Lack of paperwork cannot be used to dismiss any claims. The Department of State will provide necessary information to prove the employee was not wrongfully terminated. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. The Department of State will provide information to prove employees were not wrongfully terminated. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017 for not providing equal protections to LGBTI families of State Department officers overseas. He emphasized his support for the LGBTI community and appointed a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. In 2015, the Department appointed the first Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons to promote LGBTI rights worldwide. In the past, the Department, like many others, discriminated against employees based on perceived sexual orientation, leading to resignations and refusals to hire certain applicants. The Department of State apologizes for past discrimination against LGBTI persons, acknowledging historical wrongs and reaffirming commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also offers a formal apology for these actions. The Department of State apologizes for past discrimination against LGBTI persons and reaffirms commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also offers a formal apology for encouraging the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies. The Department of State apologizes for past discrimination against LGBTI persons and reaffirms commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also apologizes for its role in encouraging the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies at the Department of State, in response to investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and the employment of "moral perverts by Government Agencies". Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with a public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display oral history material. The exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center must be installed within a year, provide access to reports, and display oral history material from affected employees or their family members. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 100 days of this Act, addressing countries denying visas to Foreign Service personnel's spouses based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include ending visa reciprocity with such countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish a board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Advancement Board will hear testimony from LGBTQI employees regarding discrimination they have faced, and will issue reports annually for 5 years. The Advancement Board will collect testimony from LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families on discrimination due to sexual orientation. A report will be submitted to Congress annually for 5 years with comments and recommendations for improvement to prevent discrimination. The report to Congress will include comments and recommendations for improving the Department of State to prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation. The report will be private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and the Advancement Board.
